ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Basic insights into coding in MATlab.
I gained basic understanding of computational modeling as well as experience with using matlab to model biological systems and occurences.
The basics of matlab

Learned a lot about how to code in MatLab and about how to make simulations in MatLab for whatever we are learning. Lots of statistics involved in this class as well, especially how to interpret data rather than just finding numbers, understanding what those numbers mean.
I learned how to use Matlab to code specific functions and learned what different operations meant and how they can be used
You learn the basics of how to use matlab, and at the end of the course do deeper data analysis
basic applications for Matlab and various statistically important values.
How to model biological systems and use Matlab.
i learned how to use matlab in order to create surface plots, mimic random walk, brownian motion, etc.
I learned how to use Matlab and apply it to scientific domains.
Explored some basic concepts in MATLAB as well as in biomedical engineering.
How to use MATLAB

I learned the fundamentals of Matlab programming (syntax, statistics, logic, etc.) as well as the origins of many important statistical quantities such as variance, standard error oof the mean, standard deviation, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class was very dry and not very engaging overall-- the lectures are mostly running through codes that often go very quickly and can be hard to follow.
The course seemed unstructured and there wasnt any clear feedback. It was difficult to advance in my learning and I felt like i was always trailing behind.

Weakness: Very monotone professor, the content went very slow and needed more concise and engaging structure. PSETs were designed for those who knew Matlab already, very tough for those who were familiar. The grading was very erratic.

I think this course suffers from a lack of engagement. It was very boring to watch someone code for the entirety of class, and even when we did have those quizzes on some days, it was extremely rushed and stressful. I liked the content, and the structure of the class generally was very good with the multiple units and such. But engagement was definitely a low point for me.
This course is very coding heavy and was not incredibly engaging and I sometimes felt like the material could have been shared in a more interesting and engaging manner.
Mak is not a great lecturer and it's very hard to keep engaged with the class.

I benefited from this course because of the good availability from the TAs to meet and understand certain problem sets/lectures more. I felt this class was harder to follow given the lecture setup, but the grading is beneficial because it helps you focus more on your creativity rather than stress about the grade.

Lectures were very often confusing even to students who put a lot of effort into understanding. Derivations often skipped many steps and slides included many variables that were not explicitly labeled. This could be improved by going over examples with real numbers rather than a variable. This would both help everyone understand what each variable represented and what sort of calculations Matlab is preforming under the hood.
lectures were semi unorganized and hard to follow. i think if there was more guidance on the final projects, it would have helped immensely.
The course felt unorganized and some parts were repetitive or unnecessary.

The strengths of the course is that the homeworks and practice exams resemble the exams, the homeworks are based off lecture material, and that the TF's are very helpful. One weakness is that sometimes expectations were a bit unclear for certain homework problems, but overall the class was quite a positive experience.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: the teaching and personal office hours were great as well as the student to student engagement for class assignments
This class did not succeed with covid. It was one of the toughest classes that I could keep up with virtually. My engagement could not be maintained and the class was not structured well.
I think this class did a very good job adapting to the virtual environment.
The lectures were recorded live which I thought worked fine. Working on projects and things over Zoom also were fine. TAs and ULAs were also very helpful and available to meet over Zoom.
I think the online lecture worked, but this class is better taught in person due to the many screens you need to have open while following along.
Lecture was often not as engaging as it could have been. Problem sets also seemed to escalate in difficulty very quickly and favored students who had previous programming experience.
Having the lectures recorded was especially helpful because it allowed me to learn the content even when I could not attend the live class.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Take it if you are BME
I would only recommend for the major requirement.
No
Probably not unless you really need it and are set on biomedical engineering. Do not take this course as a way to know if you will like BME, as it was not representative of what BME is.
No. Only if you have to take it. The class was structured poorly during covid and was not interesting.

If you like coding, then yes for sure. It was rally fun to revisit computer science and this class had a good mix of fun coding and challenging problems that were still very doable! If you do not like coding, do not take this class because that is all it is.
If you have to take it for BME major then yes, but otherwise no - it is fairly time consuming and I don't feel like it teaches you many skills that can be applied elsewhere.
It started off fine work-wise but the last two p-sets are absolute hell and the final project/exam combo is insanely annoying and stress-inducing.
I would recommend this course if you really enjoy data analysis through coding and matlab, or if it is a requirement for your major
This course is required for the BENG major but I would certainly warn students that the class has a sharp learning curve and takes a long time. Working together on problem sets is a must.
I would only recommend this if you need to take it.
I would recommend this course to another student but only if they are a biomedical engineering major.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: n/a
The class included live virtual lectures, however, each lecture was recorded for students who were unable to attend.
Recorded lecture
We had 1 asynchronous lecture. Prof and TA office hours and peer tutoring on zoom were also made available.
Lectures were also recorded.
None
lectures were also recorded, and also had live discussion sections
recorded lecture

We had live virtual lectures that were also recorded for our viewing convenience. The TF's also held weekly Q&A sessions as well as office hours that were helpful in completing the homework assignment.
